ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot while taking this course and I greatly improved my speaking, listening, and writing skills from SPAN 110. I learned a variety of verbal tenses and moods and a lot of useful vocabulary from technology to the workplace, to home life and travel. This course was super useful in refining my existing Spanish skills from 110 and building my confidence with speaking.

This course gave me a better understanding of writing, reading, and speaking Spanish. The course covers a fair number of tenses and grammar sections and gets students to a low level of conversational.
I learned more Spanish grammar and vocabulary.
More in depth understanding of Spanish grammar: commands, past and future tenses. Better cultural understandings of Spanish-speaking countries.
Continuation of basic Spanish, including vocabulary, grammar, speaking, listening, and writing skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: I loved how the smaller class sizes for this course gave me lots of engagement with the professor even while fully virtual. I loved the projects we had to do and I think they really helped me improve my confidence with speaking while also giving me a chance to learn more about the Spanish speaking world. I did like how we had freedom to pick what topics interested us and that aspect of the course really made me feel more excited about class. I loved Professor Tortora's energy; she really made this class amazing. 

Weaknesses: The course moved really quickly through some of the material. I wish we could spend more than a week on some of the units especially towards the end of the course however, I totally understand the time constraints.

Professor Tortora was incredibly kind. Even though languages are absolutely not my strong suit, she made the semester much more enjoyable. You learn a lot of vocab, grammar, etc. The only weakness I would say is that there are can be an emphasis on culture to the detriment of actual learning. Cultural understanding is of course key, but I feel like an emphasis on conversation (what a vast majority of L2 students will use the course for) would be awesome.

For some reason it never really felt like we were spending much time with the material. I think we maybe focused a little too much on grammar and supplemental exercises at the expense of vocab and speaking.
This course would obviously be much more effective in person, but having such a small class virtually was very nice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how we were able to practice speaking one-on-one in breakout rooms. Although it was definitely not as engaging as in person learning, I don't think any aspects could be feasibly improved using zoom as a platform. The course ran as well as possible given the online platform.
I thought the course worked well over Zoom. I'm never as comfortable speaking on zoom which doesn't help, but I can't think of much to improve it.
The zoom classes worked out pretty well, and I liked the asynchronous days. I don't think there was much to be improved in terms of the remote learning aspect.
The partner video recordings weren't very helpful. The cultural projects helped with learning.

Ultimately, I appreciate that this class did not meet M-F, but I think that has probably resulted in less immersion and rigor than usual L2 Spanish. Also, not meeting every day meant that I always felt like I was missing or forgetting homework assignments.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to other students. It greatly improved my Spanish skills in such a short period of time. Be prepared to study a lot outside of class if you want to do well but there is definitely a lot of support if you need help.

If you want to learn spanish (or have to do a language requirement), yes! I don't love languages and struggled at times, but it's a well-taught course and not too brutal. Definitely take with Tortora, she's great!
I would, but mainly because I think Spanish is a good language to learn. There was nothing particularly outstanding about Spanish 120 that would make me recommend it.
Yes because while it can be a lot of work compared to other classes, it helps you learn and apply Spanish at a considerably fast pace.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Asynchronous class days with extra homework.
